title: What do we mean by dehydrated sodium ions? - Quora

response.answer_text: My old chemistry teacher used to phrase it like this “Flowerpot”: a pot for flowers. “Beer Bottle”: a bottle for beer. “Reaction kinetics” : the kinetics of the reaction in his spirit: “Dehydrated Sodium ions” sodium ions which are dehydrated.  When we put e.g. sodium chloride in water it forms hydrated ions: i.e. sodium is surrounded with water molecules which stabilizes the cation.  Sodium hydration is rather strong; when the cation moves around in solution the water molecule shell moves with it. So in water sodium is hydrated. I can only guess in which context you are asking about ‘dehydrated’ sodium. but e.g. take crown-ethers: depending on the cavity some are capable of forming a strong complex with sodium. If you would put such a crown ether in an organic solvent together with the salt. They are able to make the salt soluble in the organic solvent. You could call it ‘dehydrated’ sodium-ions This is e.g. used in making so-called ‘purple’ benzene: KMnO4 in benzene using a crown-ether: you end up with ‘naked’ permanganate, this can be used to oxidize products in an organic solvent.

The question is hard to pin down for meaning. If you are referring to an anhydrous sodium salt, such as Na2SO4, it could refer to the water-free form of the salt that forms hydrates (with a specific number of water molecules incorporated into the crystal lattice). For example Na2SO4.7H2O and Na2SO4.10H2O (Glauber’s salt) are stoichiometrically fixed hydrated salts. Above a certain temperature (usually a bit above 100 C) the water disappears leaving “anhydrous” sodium AND sulfate ions.
